displayed_text: Patient: Do you know that for sure? Doctor: Were married to people in England, had children in England. So, I’m English, right? And, then, my moth --- my grandmother’s German. My grandfather is English. So I’m going to do my Ancestry.com just to confirm, um, you know, those are my things. Family Member: I betcha you’re German, like us, yeah. Doctor: No English. I don’t even know how it’s possible because Doctor: It came back, like, I was German. My mother is Italian. That was there. The German was there, but it didn’t even mention English. And then, there was a little note, saying, “A low probability, four percent, English.” Like, no, that’s impossible because, English, English, English, English. Doctor: I see all of this, and I’m like, hmmm, I wonder if one of my great grandfathers is not English. (Laughs) Patient: He might have been a Norman. Doctor: He might have been! Patient: Which would be worse than anything. Doctor: Maybe they were, yeah. I don’t know. No, I think, that’s French, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: No, I don’t have any French. Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe

Doctor: Didn’t mean to interrupt you. Doctor: The light’s going to stay on? Family Member: She’s upstairs. Doctor: New patient? Family Member: Yep. Doctor: Oh, okay. Family Member: Study patient. Well, not study. Off study. Doctor: But, oh my. Oh my. Family Member: Hi, Dr. H___. Doctor: Hi. Lovely to see your father. (Laughs) Doctor: It’s amazing. Just waiting on the final stuff from administration. Everything else is okeydokey. So he’ll take his time filling out this lovely paperwork while you do damage control and try to fix our inpatient unit, please. Doctor: Shoot. Patient: I’ve got several questions for ya now. If I get the drug, what are the most common side effects?

Patient: Alright. Doctor: Back off a little. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Sit tight. You know who’s coming next. Patient: My buddy. Doctor: M___. Patient: Oh, M___. Doctor: Oh. Patient: My papers. I’m going to have paper to sign this way. Doctor: Of course. There’s always papers to sign. Patient: How long do you think before we actually start? Doctor: Uh, well it’s up to you but probably in a week or two. I wanna to get going. Patient: Okay.

Patient: That’s the one. R____ Doctor: You’ll take that for thirty days, and that will be sent there electronically, so you would be able to pick it up later today. Patient: Okay. Eh, any particular time of day? I’m sure it will come with, just as long as it is around the same time every day. Healthcare Professional: It just says “take it approximately, about the same time each day.” And you can take it with or without food. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And that will just cause, uh, a little bit of soft stool. Family Member: And it doesn’t counter testosterone production, just with the cancer using it. Doctor: Correct. Uh, the medicine in two weeks will get rid of production. Healthcare Professional: It’s a little due in two weeks, when you come in for your injection. You’ll have another chemo class, uh, um, uh, we’ll have you do the chemo which is normally mornings, um, I think. I think it is eight o’clock or eight fifteen that they start. Patient: Okay. Healthcare Professional: So, you could do the chemo class and then get your injection afterwards. Patient: Okay, that’ll work.

Family Member: You don't know yet if you want to do the trial. Patient: If I do the trial. I take what they give me. Family Member: Oh, that's right. Doctor: Yeah there's no choice there. Family Member: So if he wants to go somewhere, what’s the longest period of time he can be gone? Doctor: Oh. Well, probably three or four weeks Family Member: You can handle that. Doctor: Yeah, there is like a you know, plus minus, so if it’s like a special thing you know, might be five or six weeks so we can work with you guys. Because people have lives and they take vacation, they have other things they gotta do. Family Member: Right Doctor: That isn’t just cancer. Family Member: Actually I thought it was going to be worse, but you’re saying it’s every three weeks or so. I’m pretty surprised. I’m surprised. Doctor: Yeah, for standard dosing, just no trial, just once for an hour every three weeks is the infusion. Of course you know, I K_____ world that's a half a day, but still, it's not you know, every day you have to be here or anything like that.

Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses.

Patient: Yes. It is. It’s the same thing. Doctor: Yes. So I would say, uh, I think that’s not going to work. That would be my- Patient: Yeah. They don’t, they don’t, they don’t- Doctor: From what I know. From what I know about it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um, so this is what the compound is. It’s called, amygdalin. And this is, it has cyanide. There it is, cyanide. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, supposedly, this gets removed from this, what is it? Some sugar. Uh, but in humans, it just, we just don’t, we don’t have that enzyme. Patient: The enzyme to break it down? Doctor: Yeah. So- Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, yeah, the HIV, I don’t, I can, I’ll look again, but the last time I, there’s no trials that I know of that are in prostate cancer.

Patient: All right. Sounds good. Doctor: Yes. Is this a? He can do a new activation code? Healthcare Professional: Yeah. Doctor: Sounds good. Other questions for me? Patient: No, I think I understand where we're going. Right now, we haven't any delineated factors that we have to charge in any direction so. Doctor: Good. So there are study options and then we have to do usual care then Patient: Right. Okay. Yeah sounds good. Doctor: You’ll get your orders to get your blood work, the Aximun scan maybe at our baby site, you know. Patient: Okay Doctor: So, we'll get into a radiology schedule- Patient: All right. Doctor: -uh as we need it, if I find more out by the end of the week, but how to get it scheduled. I’ll let you know.

Patient: trying to do the best I can health wise and… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …and uh uh as far as uh you know relationship-wise uh I I you know I meet people you know ladies and they get to like me, but they won’t to another step then it just seems like my physical part down there they’re trying to come in but they won’t. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And so.. Doctor: Alright. It takes up to a year Patient: I’m still having problems. Doctor: It takes a year generally and your surgery was when August? Patient: Uhh September. Doctor: September and so do you have any flows at all? Patient: Uh no you know it acting like it wanna but never… Doctor: And you’re taking the medicine?

Family Member: It’s the placebo thing? Doctor: Right. So, it’s placebo in the sense that the new drug is not guaranteed but it’s not placebo in the sense everybody gets chemo. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: So, if there’s, you know, you’re guy one and you’re guy two you both get chemo no matter what. You might get drug and you might not. Patient: I got you, okay. Doctor: One of them you know. The other one you don’t. So, some it’s like oh, I’m just gonna get stuff infused in but we all kind of go gee, I wonder and it becomes a topic every time. The nurses try to guess. Everybody tries to guess. No one knows the answer except the people who actually hold the key. And then the other one is you know whether you get it or not because they just tell you okay, you’re just getting the chemo. But, the difference is you know everybody gets the chemo. That’s your standard drug. Nobody gets gipped out of that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, a good question. It’s something that I have to always make sure people understand. At this stage in the game you should never be on a placebo only trial. Like it can never be either drug X or you’re crap out of luck. No, that’s never gonna happen. Okay? Patient: Okay. Okay. Doctor: And if anybody ever offers you that, that’s bad news. That’s just ethically wrong. So, we have a lot of watchdogs, safeguards, everybody’s looking to make sure that we don’t do something like that. Patient: Okay, Alright. Doctor: Yeah, keep going.

Patient: Okay, alright. That’s cool. Doctor: So you duke it out with your wife – Patient: Yeah. Doctor: - in terms of whether you go or not, that’s on you. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You just know, I have to have you be careful. Patient: I know. Doctor: Okay? Patient: I know. Now doc let me ask you this here. Doctor: Yeah. Yes and then I got to run and answer this page. Shoot. Patient: Yeah. Um (pause) Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: - okay, for the weakness for being tired.

Patient: Right. Family Member: Oh okay. Doctor: So I think I cannot do a whole lot by the report, I do need to look at the actual scan which I will do right now. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So I’ll tell you about both those things I’m hoping today before you leave. Patient: Before we leave. Doctor: So we make some decisions. Patient: Anything else? Family Member: No unless you want to ask her about… Patient: No. Doctor: What? Laughs]] Patient: Oh I got a little inflammation from the penis um well inversion you know and you’re gonna get urine up in there and it’s gonna get inflamed. I’ve been using my statin ointment and that helps somewhat, but uh…

Patient: Merci Beaucoup. Doctor: Hope for the best right? Patient: I’m still recovering from the call and everybody keeps pushing their hand out. Why don’t you do the fist bump? Doctor: Yeah the first bump. Yeah I guess I should get with the times. Patient: I guess the fist bump is less contagious isn’t it? Doctor: Okay now maybe. Yeah you’re right. Although my son has told me that is - Family Member: Out? Doctor: -would be very weird if I did it. (Laughter) Doctor: Yeah there are some words that are off limits for me. Patient: It’s medical purposes. Doctor: Yeah exactly. No don’t try to be cool with your kid.

Family Member: It’s almost like a motivation machine. Doctor: Wow. Family Member: It doesn’t make him drowsy at all. Doctor: Now, does it uh cause you any problems, though? The Norco doesn’t constipate you? Patient: No. Doctor: Does it help with the pain? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up. Family Member: It went up. Yes. Doctor: From four to nine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay? Family Member: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. I like that. Doctor: Yeah, so we have a plan either Patient: Okay. Doctor: way and I’ll, you know, continue to sort of work through this Patient: Okay. Doctor: . Now, in the meantime, I don’t like you in pain and I think that having a small dose of narcotics like Norco Patient: Okay. Doctor: which is a combination sort of Tylenol with an opiate drug. Obviously, for any narcotics you take enough of it you don’t need it, you can get addicted. It’s just you know all the rage that’s going on Patient: Right. Doctor: but our cancer patients are in a different pool. You have cancer not treated, you’re in pain, we take narcotics. It’s at this moment the best option. Okay? Patient: Okay, yes. Doctor: So, don’t sit there and say wow, I haven’t taken it in five days, I can’t stand it anymore and now I’m gonna pop it. That’s not the life I want you to live. Patient: That’s what I do.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.strongly agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::strongly agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.strongly agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::strongly agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American
